title: Buoyant force objects stacked on block

content.question: A student places a wooden block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> in a container of water. The block floats with half of its volume above the surface of the water. The student then begins to stack small objects on top of the block until the wooden block is completely submerged but none of the objects stacked on top are submerged. What is the buoyant force acting on the block now?

choices.label: The buoyant force is equal to <math alttext="m g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></math>.

The buoyant force is greater than <math alttext="m g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></math> but less than <math alttext="2 m g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></math>.
The buoyant force is equal to <math alttext="2 m g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></math>.
The buoyant force is greater than <math alttext="2 m g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></math>.

content.answer: The buoyant force is equal to <math alttext="2 m g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></math>.
